item.title: pixi
item.description:
Developing a prototype game using Pixi.js

12/26/2015 - Created a kind of hello world to pixi js, a rotating bunny

item.title: morse
item.description:
A simple morse code converter script

When I was dabbling in javascript, this is one of the first codes that I made. Sadly, the previous code has been lost in the oblivion of deleted blogspot sites. More than 5 years later, here’s an iteration.

I’m very proud of the code for this one when compared to the code I made years before.

item.title: hello
item.description:
A small snippet that embeds js into a Hugo post

The button below executes a function from /js/hello.js

Source:

{ {< script "/js/hello.js" >}}
{ {< verbatim >}}
<button onclick="Hello('World')">Click Me!</button>
{ {< /verbatim >}}

<!-- /layouts/shortcodes/script.html -->
<script type="text/javascript" src="{{ .Get 0 }}"></script>

<!-- /layouts/shortcodes/verbatim.html -->
{{ .Inner }}

There might be an easier way to do this but so far I haven’t found anything from the docs.

item.title: smalltalk
item.description:
I’ve always been an expert in forgetting faces. Or names. Lately they have been getting worse. Was it always like this?

At first, they were unnoticeable things. Inconspicious things that is not even worthy to be remembered. It is normal to forget names and faces and places and things.

I would also like to mention that my eyesight has been getting worse lately. I’m 24 with astigmatism and over 150⁄150+ vision.

As an armchair optometrist/psychologist, I have a theory (hunch? assertion? guess?) that memory is linked to blurred vision. Once the sight has dulled, the ability to retain details in memory will dull too. It makes sense that with clear vision, a person has a lot more detail to work with when remembering things. A quick Google search does not show any studies related to this. Should I ask a psychologist? Or maybe AskScience, maybe later.

And right, it is Christmas in our side of the world. Merry christmas everyone :)
